lines.text: What, are you crying? You don't cry, all right? You keep your chin up. Come on, keep your chin up. Crying never helped anybody do anything, okay? You have a problem, you face it like a man.
[Peter continues to cry and Alan realizes what he just said]
Hey, hey, I'm sorry, okay?... Twenty-six years buried in the deepest darkest jungle, and I still became my father.

[reads]
"Every month at the quarter moon / There'll be a monsoon in your lagoon."
[Thunderclouds appear and open up]
Well, a little rain never hurt anybody.
Yeah, but a lot can kill you!
You just saw three monkeys go by on a motorcycle, didn't you?
Yeah.
Good girl.

[warning Judy and Peter]
You think that mosquitos, monkeys, and lions are bad? That is just the beginning. I've seen things you've only seen in your nightmares. Things you can't even imagine. Things you can't even see. There are things that hunt you in the night. Then something screams. Then you hear them eating, and you hope to God that you're not dessert. Afraid? You don't even know what afraid is. You would not last five minutes without me.

[reads]
"Need a hand? Well, you just wait / We'll help you out... we each have eight."
[Spiders appear]

[stuck in quicksand]
Stop giving me things that come apart!

[reads]
"At night they fly, you better run / These winged things are not much fun."
[Sarah and Alan look at each other in confusion until they hear bats echoing in the fireplace]
What was that?
I - I don't know.

[fearfully]
Put it away, Alan!
So, when can you start?
Well, actually, Martha and I were thinking of taking a little skiing holiday in the Canadian Rockies.
No!
[all is silent for a brief second]
Sorry. We just...
...need you to get that marketing done on the new line, pronto.
No problem. No problem. You know, I can probably start next week.
[Alan and Sarah have finished the game. Sam reenters the house]
Forgot my speech notes.

[runs up to Sam and hugs him]
I'm so glad you're back.
I've only been gone 5 minutes.

[crying]
It seems like a lot longer for me.
I thought you told me you were never going to talk to me again.
Whatever I said, Dad, I'm sorry.
[They hug again]
Oh, Alan, I was angry, OK? And I'm sorry, too. Look, you don't have to go to Cliffside if you don't want to. Let's talk it over tomorrow. Man to man.
How about father to son?

[reads]
"Don't be fooled, it isn't thunder / Staying put would be a blunder."
Run! IT'S A STAMPEDE!
What happened to you, you shave with a piece of glass?
What happened to you, the Clampetts have a yard sale? What do you want, I never shaved before.

[in horror]
Judy!
What?
What happened?
I thought I could end the game myself. I was only ten spaces away.

[reads]
"A law of Jumanji having been broken / You will slip back even more than your token."
You tried to cheat?
No, I tried to drop the dice so they'd land on twelve.
Oh, okay, honey. Well, that would be cheating.

[in terror]
Peter, your hands! Look at your hands!
[Peter sees that he is growing monkey fur on his hands as a punishment]

[in terror]
"A hunter from the darkest wild / Makes you feel just like a child."
What is it?
Van Pelt.
You might've told us there was a man in there with a rifle that hunts people.
Well, I didn't know, okay? It's just the roll of the dice.

[sarcastically]
Is he the reason you didn't wanna play?

[scoffs]
You didn't want to play either, Mr. We-Started-Something-26-Years-Ago-And-Now-We've-Gotta-Finish-It?

[leveling his gun at Alan]
End of the line, Sonny Jim. Game's up. Start running.

[as Sarah runs into the room]
... No.
Aren't you afraid?
I'm terrified. But my father says you should always face what you're afraid of.

[chuckles]
Good lad. You're finally acting like a man.
[aims his gun at Alan]
Any last words?

]
Jumanji.
Eh?

[slightly louder]
Jumanji.
[Van Pelt cocks his gun... ]

[runs to shield Alan]
NO!
[the rules of Jumanji]
a game for those who seek to find / a way to leave their world behind. You roll the dice to move your token, doubles gets another turn, the first player to reach the end wins.
do not begin unless you intend to finish. The exciting consequences of the game / will vanish only when a player has reached Jumanji and called out its name.
Alan, please, last time I played this game, it ruined my life.

[laughs]
It ruined your life? "In the jungle, you must wait 'til the dice read five or eight."
I was a little girl, Alan. You disappeared, and a bunch of bats surrounded me and chased me down the street. I was afraid. I'm sorry, Alan. No one believed me. I was all alone.
So was I. For 26 years, Sarah.

[reads]
"There is a lesson you will learn / Sometimes you must go back a turn."

[about Van Pelt]
Well, have you ever thought about just sitting down and talking about your differences?
What are you, crazy? The man has a gun!
Don't ever call me crazy, Alan! EVER! Because everyone in this town has called me crazy ever since I told the cops that you were sucked into a board game.
[Alan is about to play a turn on the game, and he suddenly cracks up a joke]
Okay, it's my turn. I got it! "Colonel Mustard in the Library with a wrench."
[chuckles]
"Clue."

[reads]
"His fangs are sharp, he likes your taste / Your party better move post-haste."
I don't like the sound of that.
[a lion suddenly appears]
Twenty-six years ago, you played a game with a little boy down the street. A game with drums.
How do you know that?
I was that little boy, Sarah.

[hushed]
Alan...
[she falls over in a faint]

[to Alan]
You killed her.
[after a big vine has swiped Carl's car]
Fine! Take it!

[to Van Pelt, who is purchasing a new gun]
You're not a postal worker, are you?

[reads]
"This will not be an easy mission / Monkeys slow the expedition."

[reads]
"Beware of the ground for which you stand / The floor is quicker than the sand."
[suddenly sinks into quicksand]

[reads]
"You're almost there with much at stake / But now the ground begins to quake."

[reads]
'They grow much faster than bamboo / Take care or they'll come after you'.
[Jungle plants start to grow]
Oh, great...

[whimpers]
Oh, God, tell me this isn't happening!
Oh, it is.
[Alan, Sarah, Peter, and Jud huddle close to each other in the middle of the room]
Stay away from the walls; don't touch anything. No quick movements.

[reads]
"A tiny bite can make you itch / Make you sneeze, make you twitch."
[Mosquitoes appear]
Bats aren't what I worry about in this house anyway.
What would you worry about?
Well, personally, I wouldn't want to live in a house where someone was murdered.
Murdered?
Yep, little Alan Parrish. I'd say his father did it. There's 1,001 places he could've hid the body in this house - especially if he chopped it up first.
Listen, Carl. I know it doesn't mean much after twenty-six years. But I'm sorry. I'm sorry.
Sorry for what?
It's me, Alan.
[1869, Benjamin and Caleb are burying a chest]
What if someone digs it up?

[dramatically]
May God have mercy on his soul.

[about a noise she just heard]
Did you hear anything a little while ago?

[shakes his head]
Do you miss mom and dad?
No.
Liar. If you don't cut that out, they're gonna send you to a shrink.
Where do you think they're gonna send you if you don't start talking?
Do you know what it was like to have witnessed Alan Parrish's murder? Do you think anyone showed up at my 14th birthday party?
Where's Sir Sav-A-Lot?
Monroe and Elm!
The Episcopal Church.
No, it's not a church anymore. Now it's a Speedy Burger. Or at least it was. I don't know what's left of it. People in this town are goin' loopy.
Alan, you wrestled an alligator for me.
It was a crocodile. Alligators don't have that little fringe on their hind leg.
My mistake.
Alan, are you ready?
There is no "ready".
Play the game, Sarah.

[whispering]
Oh, no, no, no.
All right. Just give me the dice, and you can go home. You don't have to play.
Oh, thank you.
[Sarah gives Alan the dice but moves his hand making Sarah roll as Alan laughs; Sarah loses it]
Oh, my god! How could you do that?
It's the law of the jungle, Sarah. You'll get used to it.
And I think of all the energy, I spent visualizing you as a radiant spirit.

[tries to roll the dice, but the game board doesn't recognize it]
Alan, it's not working.

[inspects the game board]
Oh, no. It's not your turn.
Yeah, I rolled first and then Peter twice because he got doubles. Now it's my turn again.
No, look. Two of these pieces are yours, right? What about the other pieces?
[spots his old game piece]
The elephant was mine. You're playing the game I started in 1969. I'm going to have to play.
[Judy offers the dice to him]
It's not my turn.
Whose turn is it?
Sarah Whittle.
Listen, I know you're upset and all, but I kind of feel we should finish the game.
We? Why do you need me?
Well, just in case any scary stuff comes out. Plus, there's a lion in my aunt's bedroom. What am I supposed to do about that?
What do I look like, a Ringling Brother?
But she'll be home soon!
Won't she be surprised! I hope she's not allergic to cats.
Do you know what happened to this shoe factory?
Yeah, it folded up, like everything else in this town. It's pretty cold out there. How about some coffee?
Why would they close Parrish Shoes?

Well, when his kid ran away, Sam put everything he had to find him - his time, his money, everything. After a while, he stopped coming to work. He just quit caring. I don't think anybody loved his boy more than Sam did.
[after Alan jumps onto Carl's cruiser]
What year is it?
It was brand new.
No, what year is it?
Uh, 1995, remember?

[in shock]
'95?
You got some ID? Oh, let me guess, you probably left it in your other Tarzan outfit, right?

[to himself]
26 years!
Are you from around here?
I was. But I've been in Jumanji.
Indonesia. He was in the Peace Corps.

[to Alan]
You miserable coward! Come back and face me like a man!
[Alan hurls a sword at Van Pelt, which halts him... briefly]
Not good enough, Sonny Jim! I'm coming, ready or not...
Oh, no. The game thinks I rolled.
What do you mean "the game thinks"?

[angry]
I guess I'm not ready for Cliffside then!

[at the door, shouts]
We're taking you there next Sunday! And I don't want to hear another word about it!
You won't! I'm never talking to you again!
[Sam slams the door behind him as Alan tears up the brochure in anger]

[Van Pelt hands an empty elephant gun shell to the gun store salesman]
You know they stopped making these in 1903...?
Damn. I'll be needing a replacement weapon.
I thought I lost you again.
Thanks for sticking around this time.

[whispers]
I knew this was going to be a bad day.

[holds her hand]
Hey, come on, you'll be fine. We just have to keep our heads. Roll with the punches.
Peter, take this suitcase up to the attic, then we can all have ice cream.
[mumbles to herself]
And bourbon.

[after Alan got chased by Van Pelt]
What is the deal with you and this guy?
He's a hunter. He kills things, that's what he does. And right now, he wants to hunt me and kill me, okay?
Why you?

Why me? I don't know. Everything about me he finds offensive. You'd think it'd be a waste of his time. Maybe he needs something for his wall, you know, a Parrish - something to go between penguin and partridge.
It's me! It's me, Alan, Mom and Dad! I'm home! I'm back!

[Alan grabs her]
Oh, get your hands off me!
The game is not over yet, Sarah!
Well, it is for me! You are not in the jungle anymore. Stop this, you don't treat people like this!
Just because you're a Parrish doesn't mean you can hang around with my girlfriend.
We're just friends.

[chuckles]
Not anymore.
Now, let's try to relax, finish our dinner, and talk about something else.

Well, we found out why you got this house so cheap. 26 years ago, a kid named Alan Parrish used to live here. Then one day, he just disappeared, because his parents chopped him up in little pieces and hid him in the walls.
Okay, that's it. I am sick and tired of your lies, young lady. You're grounded.

[leaves]
Fine, there's nowhere to go in this stupid town, anyway. And just for your information, that wasn't a lie.
I should've been a fireman!
Peter hasn't spoken a word since it happened.
Oh. Oh, my. I'm so sorry. How terribly awful.

It's OK. We barely even knew our parents. They were always away. Skiing, gambling in Monte Carlo, on safari in darkest Africa. We didn't even know if they loved us. But when the Sheik's yacht went down, they managed to write us a really beautiful goodbye note that was found floating in a champagne bottle amongst the debris.
[Starts crying]
Excuse me.
[Judy leaves the room. Camera pans away to show that she is actually laughing at the lie she just told the Estate Agent]

[to the Estate Agent]
They were very devoted parents. Car crash in Canada.

[in 1995]
Alan, they're here.
[Alan and Sarah greet Judy and Peter]
Don't worry. I've done this before. Once.
[after hearing drums]
I'm going to Motel Six!
Oh, for heaven's sake!
Sarah and I would like to get out of the floor, so it's your turn, Peter.

[a pelican has grabbed the game]
WHY DIDN'T YOU GRAB THE GAME, PETER?
[chases after pelican]

[to dejected Peter]
Just ignore him, honey, he's a Libra.
[calls to Alan]
WHERE ARE YOU GOING?
He'll head for water!
Our parents are dead too. They were in the Middle East negotiating peace when...
[gets nudged by Peter]
